Measles.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by Measles virus (RNA virus, Paramyxoviridae family, Morbillivirus genus). Enters via respiratory mucosa → multiplies in local lymphoid tissue → viremia → skin, conjunctiva, and respiratory tract
ModeOfTransmission: Extremely contagious – 90% attack rate among susceptible individuals
Measles.IncubationPeriod: 7–14 days (usually 10 days to fever; 14 days to rash)
Measles.InfectivePeriod: From 4 days before rash to 4 days after rash onset

ProdromalPhase: Koplik spots: bluish-white lesions on buccal mucosa (pathognomonic)
ExanthemPhase: Starts behind ears, spreads to face → trunk → limbs

Complications: SSPE (Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis) – rare, late CNS complication
Treatment: Supportive only – antipyretics, hydration, cough relief
Vitamin A supplementation: <12 months: 1 lakh IU; ≥12 months: 2 lakh IU
Antibiotics for secondary bacterial infections
Isolation during infective period

OutbreakControl: Measles vaccine within 72 hrs of contact
Immunoglobulin within 6 days for high-risk contacts (infants, immunocompromised)

Rubella.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by the Rubella virus. Family: Togaviridae, Genus: Rubivirus. Spread via nasopharyngeal droplets → virus multiplies locally → viremia → skin & lymph nodes. Crosses placenta → causes Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) in fetuses
ModeOfTransmission: Transplacental (mother to fetus in early pregnancy)
Rubella.InfectivePeriod: 1 week before to 1 week after rash. Infants with CRS may shed virus for months

AcquiredRubella: Pink, maculopapular rash: Begins on face, spreads to trunk and limbs; Fades in 1–3 days

CongenitalRubellaSyndrome.OccursWhen: Mother is infected during first trimester
ClassicTriad: Congenital heart defects (PDA, pulmonary artery stenosis)

Treatment: Supportive: antipyretics, fluids
No antiviral therapy
Monitor pregnant women with exposure — test IgM/IgG levels

PregnancyConsideration: Women should avoid pregnancy for at least 1 month after vaccination

ErythemaInfectiosum.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by Parvovirus B19 (small, non-enveloped DNA virus). Infects erythroid precursor cells in the bone marrow → transient aplastic crisis in anemic individuals (e.g., thalassemia, sickle cell)
ErythemaInfectiosum.InfectivePeriod: During prodrome, before rash appears. Not contagious once rash is visible

ClassicalPresentation: "Slapped cheek" rash: Bright red rash on both cheeks; Followed by lacy reticular rash on arms, trunk, buttocks; Rash may wax and wane for 2–3 weeks, especially with heat or sunlight
HighRiskGroups: Pregnant women: risk of fetal hydrops (due to anemia)
Hemolytic anemias: risk of transient aplastic crisis

DifferentialDiagnosis.Drug Rash: No prodrome, may be itchy or symmetric

Complications: Transient aplastic crisis in patients with hemolytic anemia
Fetal hydrops or miscarriage if maternal infection during 1st half of pregnancy
Arthritis (self-limited) in older children and adults
Treatment: Supportive only – antipyretics, fluids
IVIG in immunocompromised patients with persistent anemia
No antiviral available
No vaccine available
Prevention: No vaccine
Hand hygiene, avoiding close contact during outbreaks
Pregnant women should avoid exposure to infected children during outbreaks
Antenatal counseling if exposure occurs

RoseolaInfantum.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by Human Herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) (most common); Sometimes HHV-7. Virus infects T-lymphocytes → transient viremia → skin and CNS involvement. Commonly affects children aged 6 months to 2 years
RoseolaInfantum.InfectivePeriod: During febrile phase (before rash appears). Not contagious once rash starts

Stage1: Child appears well despite high temperature
May have mild cold-like symptoms (cough, rhinorrhea)
Stage2: Maculopapular, pink rash: Starts on trunk, spreads to neck, face, extremities; Non-itchy, fades in 1–2 days

Complications: Reactivation in immunocompromised (e.g., HHV-6 reactivation post-transplant)
Treatment: Supportive only: Antipyretics (paracetamol), Hydration
Antivirals (ganciclovir) used only in immunocompromised
Prevention: No vaccine available
General hygiene
Avoid contact with febrile children (in infants <6 months)

HandFootAndMouthDisease.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by Coxsackievirus A16 (most common); Other causative agents: Enterovirus 71, Coxsackie A6. Virus enters via oral or respiratory route → replicates in mucosa and lymphoid tissue → viremia → skin and oral mucosa involvement. Affects mainly children <5 years
ModeOfTransmission: Direct contact with vesicle fluid or contaminated surfaces
Highly contagious, especially in daycare settings
HandFootAndMouthDisease.InfectivePeriod: Most contagious during the first week of illness. Virus can be shed in feces for several weeks after recovery
ClinicalFeatures: Painful oral ulcers: Small vesicles → ulcers on tongue, buccal mucosa, soft palate
Skin rash: Vesicular lesions on palms, soles, buttocks; May also occur on elbows, knees, or genitalia; Lesions are non-itchy, greyish with erythematous halo
Children may refuse to eat or drink due to mouth pain

DifferentialDiagnosis.Herpangina: Similar oral lesions but no rash on hands/feet
DifferentialDiagnosis.Chickenpox: Generalized rash, not restricted to hands/feet
DifferentialDiagnosis.Aphthous ulcers: Only mouth involvement, no systemic symptoms

Complications: Rarely: Aseptic meningitis, Encephalitis, Nail shedding (onychomadesis) post-recovery, Severe disease with Enterovirus 71 (e.g., pulmonary edema, myocarditis)
Treatment: Supportive therapy only: Paracetamol for fever and pain, Topical oral gels for ulcers (e.g., lignocaine gel), Maintain hydration
No antiviral treatment required
Prevention: No vaccine available (except for Enterovirus 71 in some countries, not in India)
Emphasize: Handwashing, Avoid sharing utensils or towels, Isolation of infected child during the first few days of illness

Mumps.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by the Mumps virus, an RNA virus. Family: Paramyxoviridae, Genus: Rubulavirus. Virus spreads through respiratory epithelium, followed by viremia → localizes in salivary glands, CNS, pancreas, testes/ovaries
ModeOfTransmission: Direct contact with saliva or contaminated surfaces
Highly contagious, especially in unvaccinated populations
Mumps.InfectivePeriod: 2 days before to 5 days after parotid swelling onset
ClinicalFeatures: Unilateral or bilateral parotid gland swelling (painful, tender): Swelling increases over 2–3 days; Ear may be pushed upward/outward
Pain while chewing or sour food intake
20–30% may have asymptomatic or non-specific illness

DifferentialDiagnosis.Cervical lymphadenitis: Firm, localized lymph node, no salivary pain

Complications: Orchitis (common in adolescent males; may cause infertility)
Miscarriage if infection occurs in early pregnancy
Treatment: Supportive only: Analgesics and antipyretics, Warm/cold compresses for gland pain, Adequate hydration and soft diet
Hospitalization if CNS involvement or severe complications

NonSpecificEnterovirusInfection.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by non-polio enteroviruses: Coxsackieviruses (A & B), Echoviruses, Enterovirus 71 and others. Family: Picornaviridae, Genus: Enterovirus. Virus enters via oropharynx or gastrointestinal tract, replicates in lymphoid tissue, spreads hematogenously to various organs
NonSpecificEnterovirusInfection.InfectivePeriod: Few days before onset of symptoms to 1–2 weeks after recovery. Virus may be shed in feces for several weeks

Common: May present with non-specific febrile illness
Common symptoms: Fever, malaise, sore throat; Diarrhea, vomiting; Rash (maculopapular or vesicular); Headache, irritability

DifferentialDiagnosis.Measles: 3 Cs, Koplik spots, high-grade fever, classic rash
DifferentialDiagnosis.Typhoid: Step-ladder fever, relative bradycardia, abdominal symptoms

Complications: Rare in mild cases, but may include: Aseptic meningitis, Myocarditis, Encephalitis, Neonatal sepsis-like illness, Acute flaccid paralysis (rare; more commonly seen in Enterovirus D68 or EV-A71 outbreaks)
Treatment: Supportive care: Paracetamol for fever, Fluids and rest
No specific antiviral therapy available
Hospitalization if severe systemic involvement occurs
Prevention: No vaccine for non-specific enteroviruses (except Polio, EV-71 in select countries)
Preventive measures: Hand hygiene, Safe drinking water, Proper sanitation, Avoid close contact with infected individuals

AcuteParotitis: Non-infectious: autoimmune (e.g., Sjögren’s syndrome), obstructive (e.g., ductal stones)
Etiopathogenesis.Pathophysiology: Salivary stasis or infection → glandular inflammation → swelling, pain, and systemic features in some cases

ModeOfTransmission: Viral parotitis (e.g., mumps): via respiratory droplets
Bacterial parotitis: ascending infection via Stensen’s duct, often in dehydrated or immunocompromised children
Parotitis.IncubationPeriod: For viral causes (e.g., mumps): 14 to 18 days
Parotitis.InfectivePeriod: Viral parotitis (e.g., mumps): 2 days before to 5 days after onset of glandular swelling
ClinicalFeatures: Painful swelling of one or both parotid glands: Ear pushed upward and outward; Tenderness over angle of jaw; Pain increases while chewing/sour food
Fever, malaise, headache may precede swelling
Trismus and difficulty in opening the mouth
May have purulent discharge from parotid duct (in bacterial cases)
Redness over skin in severe bacterial cases
Dehydration in infants and poor oral intake

DifferentialDiagnosis.Mumps: Bilateral, viral prodrome, no pus from duct
DifferentialDiagnosis.Bacterial Parotitis: Unilateral, pus from duct, systemic toxicity

Complications.Other: Chronic or recurrent parotitis (especially in autoimmune or ductal obstruction)

ViralParotitis: Supportive: Antipyretics, hydration, soft diet; Warm compress for pain relief
BacterialParotitis: Empirical antibiotics: e.g., Cloxacillin or Amoxicillin-clavulanate

Prevention: MMR vaccination for mumps (Live attenuated)
Good oral hygiene
Adequate hydration, especially in ill or postoperative patients
Prompt treatment of oral infections

InfectiousMononucleosis.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by Epstein–Barr Virus (EBV). Family: Herpesviridae, Genus: Lymphocryptovirus. EBV infects B lymphocytes and epithelial cells of the oropharynx. Transmitted via saliva → local replication in oropharynx → viremia → generalized lymphoid tissue involvement
InfectiousMononucleosis.InfectivePeriod: Several weeks to months, even after resolution of symptoms. Virus may be shed intermittently in saliva lifelong

OtherFindings: Hepatosplenomegaly (may lead to risk of rupture)

DifferentialDiagnosis.Streptococcal pharyngitis: No lymphocytosis, rapid improvement with antibiotics
DifferentialDiagnosis.CMV mononucleosis: Similar but milder pharyngitis, negative heterophile test
DifferentialDiagnosis.Toxoplasmosis: Similar nodes, but no sore throat or splenomegaly

Treatment: Supportive care: Antipyretics, hydration, rest; Soft diet if sore throat
Corticosteroids in severe tonsillar hypertrophy or airway compromise
Avoid ampicillin/amoxicillin (rash risk)
Avoid contact sports for 3–4 weeks due to splenic rupture risk
Prevention: No vaccine available
Avoid saliva exposure from symptomatic individuals
Maintain good hygiene practices (no sharing of drinks or utensils)

Chickenpox.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV). Family: Herpesviridae. Primary infection causes varicella (chickenpox). Virus enters via respiratory mucosa or conjunctiva → replicates in lymph nodes → viremia → characteristic skin rash. Establishes latency in dorsal root ganglia, can reactivate as herpes zoster (shingles)
ModeOfTransmission: Highly contagious, especially in closed settings
Chickenpox.InfectivePeriod: 1–2 days before rash onset until all lesions have crusted (usually 5–7 days after rash onset)

ClinicalFeatures.Prodrome: fever, malaise, sore throat, headache (especially in older children)
Rash: Starts as macules → papules → vesicles → pustules → crusts
Involves trunk, face, scalp, then extremities
Lesions in different stages at the same time (classic feature)

DifferentialDiagnosis.Hand-Foot-Mouth Disease: Rash on palms/soles, oral ulcers, no trunk dominance
DifferentialDiagnosis.Impetigo: Pustular or honey-colored crusts, bacterial etiology

Complications: Secondary bacterial infection of skin (most common)
Pneumonia, especially in adolescents and adults
Congenital varicella syndrome (if maternal infection in early pregnancy)
Neonatal varicella (if mother develops varicella 5 days before to 2 days after delivery)
Treatment: Supportive care in healthy children: Antipyretics (avoid aspirin), Antihistamines for itching, Maintain skin hygiene to prevent superinfection
Antivirals (Acyclovir) in: Immunocompromised children, Severe or complicated cases, Adolescents, Neonates or pregnant women with exposure
Varicella-Zoster Immunoglobulin (VZIG) for post-exposure prophylaxis in high-risk individuals
Prevention: Live attenuated varicella vaccine
Schedule: 1st dose: 15 months (IAP); 2nd dose: 4–6 years
Isolation of infected individuals until all lesions crust over
Post-exposure prophylaxis with vaccine or VZIG as indicated

HerpesSimplexVirusInfection.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by Herpes Simplex Virus: HSV-1: commonly causes orofacial (labial) herpes; HSV-2: primarily causes genital herpes. Virus infects mucocutaneous surfaces → replicates locally → travels via sensory nerves → establishes latency in dorsal root ganglia. Reactivation can occur due to stress, illness, trauma, or immunosuppression
ModeOfTransmission: Direct contact with infected saliva, mucosal secretions, or vesicular fluid
HSV-1: mostly acquired in childhood via oral contact
Vertical transmission from mother to newborn (especially HSV-2 during vaginal delivery)
HerpesSimplexVirusInfection.InfectivePeriod: Highest during active lesions. Asymptomatic viral shedding can also transmit the infection

PrimaryHSV1: Gingivostomatitis (commonest presentation): Painful oral ulcers, swollen gums (gingiva), drooling; Fever, irritability, refusal to feed; Vesicular lesions on lips, tongue, buccal mucosa; Lymphadenopathy
RecurrentHSV1: Herpes labialis (cold sores): Localized grouped vesicles at vermillion border; Tingling or burning precedes vesicles; Resolves in 5–7 days
NeonatalHSV: Can present as: Localized skin, eye, mouth disease (SEM); CNS involvement (encephalitis); Disseminated infection (life-threatening)

DifferentialDiagnosis.Hand-Foot-Mouth Disease: Rash on palms/soles, less gum involvement

Complications: Herpetic whitlow (finger lesion in healthcare workers)
Eczema herpeticum (widespread HSV in atopic dermatitis patients)
Neonatal herpes (disseminated or CNS disease; high mortality)

ModerateToSevere: Acyclovir (oral or IV depending on severity)

Prevention: Avoid contact with active lesions
Barrier methods for genital herpes
Pregnant women with active genital herpes: cesarean delivery recommended
No vaccine currently available

Poliomyelitis.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by Poliovirus, an RNA virus. Family: Picornaviridae, Genus: Enterovirus. Three serotypes: Type 1, 2, and 3 (Type 1 most commonly associated with paralysis). Virus enters via oral route, multiplies in pharynx and gut → spreads to regional lymph nodes → viremia → may invade CNS (anterior horn cells) leading to neuronal destruction
ModeOfTransmission: Highly contagious, especially in areas with poor sanitation
Poliomyelitis.InfectivePeriod: 7–10 days before onset of symptoms. Continues for up to 6 weeks in stool after infection

AbortivePolio: Symptoms: sore throat, headache, malaise, nausea
ParalyticPolio: Sudden onset flaccid paralysis (asymmetric, proximal > distal, no sensory loss)
Fever at onset or shortly before paralysis
Bulbar polio: respiratory and cranial nerve involvement
Post-polio syndrome: recurrence of weakness years later

Complications: Death (due to respiratory or bulbar failure)
Treatment: Supportive care only: Bed rest during acute phase, Pain control, Adequate hydration and nutrition
Physical therapy to maintain joint mobility and muscle strength
Ventilatory support if respiratory muscles are involved

IPV: No risk of VAPP; induces strong systemic immunity
NationalImmunizationSchedule: Pulse Polio: Additional OPV doses during national campaigns

Rabies.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by Rabies virus. Family: Rhabdoviridae, Genus: Lyssavirus. Bullet-shaped, enveloped RNA virus. Virus enters via bite/scratch → replicates in muscle → enters peripheral nerves via acetylcholine receptors → spreads centripetally to CNS → causes acute progressive encephalitis
ModeOfTransmission: Bite or scratch from infected animals (dogs, bats, cats, monkeys, etc.)
Contact with saliva or neural tissue of infected animals
Human-to-human transmission: extremely rare (organ transplant cases reported)
Rabies.IncubationPeriod: 1 to 3 months (range: a few days to a year). Shorter with deep, multiple, or head/neck bites
Rabies.InfectivePeriod: In animals: typically 3–7 days before symptoms appear until death

FuriousRabies: Fever, paresthesia at bite site (early symptom)
Hydrophobia: painful spasms triggered by attempts to drink water
Progresses to coma and death in days
ParalyticRabies: Flaccid, ascending paralysis resembling Guillain–Barré syndrome
Slower progression to coma and death

DifferentialDiagnosis.GBS: No hydrophobia, slower progression, no CNS signs
DifferentialDiagnosis.Tetanus: Spastic paralysis, jaw stiffness, risus sardonicus
DifferentialDiagnosis.Acute viral encephalitis: No bite history, different prodrome pattern

Complications: Fatal encephalitis (almost 100% mortality if symptoms appear)
Death usually within 1–2 weeks of symptom onset
Treatment: Once clinical symptoms appear, no effective treatment
Supportive ICU care
Palliative care for airway, seizures, hydration
Milwaukee Protocol: experimental, rarely successful
Emphasis is on prevention and post-exposure prophylaxis

PostExposureProphylaxis: Category I – Touching or feeding animals, licks on intact skin → No treatment
Category II – Nibbling, minor scratches (no bleeding) → Wound care + Rabies vaccine
Category III – Transdermal bites/scratches, licks on broken skin → Wound care + Rabies vaccine + Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG)
Wound care: Immediate washing with soap and water for at least 15 min
RIG: Infiltrate around wound site + IM elsewhere; Dose: 20 IU/kg (human RIG) or 40 IU/kg (equine RIG)
PreExposureProphylaxis: For high-risk individuals (veterinarians, lab workers, children in endemic areas)

DengueFever.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by Dengue virus (DENV), an RNA virus of the Flaviviridae family. Four serotypes: DENV-1 to DENV-4. Transmitted by Aedes aegypti (day-biting mosquito). Primary infection gives lifelong immunity to that serotype; secondary infection with a different serotype increases risk of severe dengue due to antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE).
DengueFever.InfectivePeriod: Humans are viremic and can infect mosquitoes from 1 day before to 5 days after onset of fever

CriticalPhase: Plasma leakage → hemoconcentration, pleural effusion, ascites
Bleeding: GI bleed, mucosal hemorrhage, DIC
RecoveryPhase: Bradycardia, convalescent rash ('white islands in sea of red')

DifferentialDiagnosis.Chikungunya: Severe joint pain, less hemorrhage, slower onset

General: Supportive care based on clinical phase
HospitalizationIndications: Warning signs (abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, mucosal bleed, lethargy, hepatomegaly, rising hematocrit with falling platelets)
DengueShockManagement: Blood products only if major bleeding

Prevention: No universally available vaccine in India (Dengvaxia not widely recommended)
Mosquito control: Eliminate breeding sites (stagnant water), use mosquito nets/repellents, wear full-sleeved clothing, daytime mosquito precautions

Chikungunya.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by Chikungunya virus (CHIKV), an RNA virus (Togaviridae family, Alphavirus genus). Transmitted by Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus. Virus replicates in skin and lymph nodes, then viremia affects joints, muscles, skin, and CNS.
ModeOfTransmission: Bite of infected Aedes mosquitoes (mostly daytime biters)
Vertical transmission (mother to fetus) possible during perinatal period
Chikungunya.InfectivePeriod: Human host is viremic and can infect mosquitoes from 1–2 days before to 5–6 days after onset of fever

AcutePhase: Severe polyarthralgia/polyarthritis (hallmark): symmetrical, often small joints (wrists, fingers, ankles), pain may be disabling
Skin rash (maculopapular), usually on trunk and limbs
PostAcuteOrChronicPhase: Arthralgia/arthritis may persist for weeks to months
More common in older children and adolescents
Mimics rheumatoid arthritis in chronic form

DifferentialDiagnosis.RheumaticFever: Migratory arthritis, carditis, prior sore throat
DifferentialDiagnosis.ViralArthritis: May resemble but less intense joint pain

Treatment: Supportive only: Paracetamol for fever and pain, adequate hydration
Avoid NSAIDs until dengue is ruled out (risk of bleeding)
Chronic joint symptoms: may require NSAIDs or short-term corticosteroids (under supervision)
Prevention: No vaccine available currently
Vector control: Eliminate breeding sites, use mosquito repellents and nets, wear protective clothing
Avoid mosquito bites during daytime

AvianInfluenza.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by Avian Influenza A viruses (notably H5N1, H7N9, H5N6). Family: Orthomyxoviridae, Genus: Influenza A. Birds (especially poultry) are natural hosts. Virus enters via inhalation or mucosal contact with infected bird secretions/excretions. Severe cases involve diffuse alveolar damage, ARDS, cytokine storm, multi-organ involvement.
ModeOfTransmission: Direct contact with infected birds or surfaces contaminated with bird droppings, saliva, or nasal secretions
Inhalation of aerosols during handling or culling of poultry
No sustained human-to-human transmission (rare close-contact cases possible)
AvianInfluenza.IncubationPeriod: 2 to 8 days (can be up to 17 days)
AvianInfluenza.InfectivePeriod: Not precisely defined; assumed to begin 1–2 days before symptom onset. Viral shedding may last up to 10 days or more, especially in severe cases.

ProgressiveIllness: GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea) may be present

DifferentialDiagnosis.BacterialPneumonia: More localized, productive cough, lobar consolidation

Complications: Death if not treated early (high case fatality rate for H5N1)
Treatment: Supportive care: oxygen, fluid management, antipyretics, mechanical ventilation if ARDS develops
Antivirals (start early): Oseltamivir (75 mg BID for 5–10 days), Zanamivir (alternative), resistance may occur
Empirical antibiotics if secondary bacterial infection is suspected
Prevention: Avoid contact with sick/dead birds or live poultry markets
Use PPE when handling birds (especially during outbreaks)
Hand hygiene and respiratory precautions
No approved universal vaccine for avian influenza in humans
Prophylactic Oseltamivir for exposed individuals in outbreak settings (under guidance)

SARS.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by SARS-CoV (a coronavirus), family Coronaviridae, genus Betacoronavirus. Origin: believed to be transmitted from civets or bats to humans. Enters respiratory tract, binds ACE2 receptors, replicates in pneumocytes, causes alveolar damage, cytokine storm, and ARDS.
ModeOfTransmission: Aerosol-generating procedures in healthcare settings (higher risk)
SARS.InfectivePeriod: Begins with onset of symptoms; peak viral shedding day 7–10; may continue up to 21 days in severely ill patients

PediatricCases: Infants: fever, cough, rhinorrhea, often no severe respiratory symptoms

DifferentialDiagnosis.Influenza: Rapid onset, seasonal occurrence, upper respiratory signs more common
DifferentialDiagnosis.HantavirusPulmonarySyndrome: Exposure to rodents, rapid pulmonary edema

Complications: High mortality in adults (~10%), especially elderly and those with comorbidities
Treatment: No specific antiviral therapy proven effective
Supportive care: oxygen therapy, mechanical ventilation if needed, fluids and electrolyte management
Experimental therapies (not standard): ribavirin, interferons, corticosteroids (used with caution)
Prevention: Infection control measures: hand hygiene, use of masks and PPE in healthcare settings, isolation of suspected/confirmed cases
No vaccine available for SARS-CoV (distinct from SARS-CoV-2)
Post-2003, SARS cases not reported, but vigilance remains essential

AidsInChildren.Etiopathogenesis: Caused by Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV). HIV-1 (most common), HIV-2 (less virulent). Virus targets CD4+ T lymphocytes, leading to gradual immune system destruction. AIDS develops when CD4 count drops significantly or with opportunistic infections/malignancies.
ModeOfTransmission: Vertical (mother-to-child) transmission: during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding
Blood transfusion (in settings without proper screening)
IncubationPeriod: Many children remain asymptomatic for months to years
Disease progression tends to be faster in infants than adults
InfectivePeriod: Risk of transmission to others via blood, body fluids, and breastfeeding

LaterChildhood: Opportunistic infections: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, TB, CMV, etc.

DifferentialDiagnosis.SevereCombinedImmunodeficiency: Presents earlier, family history, T-cell defect
DifferentialDiagnosis.Tuberculosis: May coexist; requires ruling out active TB

AntiretroviralTherapy: Goals: suppress viral load, improve immunity (CD4), prevent progression
Prophylaxis: Cotrimoxazole for Pneumocystis jirovecii (starting at 6 weeks)
INH prophylaxis for TB in endemic areas
Routine immunizations + special consideration for live vaccines
NutritionalAndPsychosocialSupport: Address school performance, mental health, and family support

Prevention: Prevention of Parent-to-Child Transmission (PPTCT): Antenatal HIV testing, ART for HIV-positive mothers, safe delivery practices, avoid breastfeeding if replacement feeding is safe, neonatal ART prophylaxis for baby, early infant diagnosis (PCR at 6 weeks)
Safe blood transfusion, sterile injections, and health education
Counseling and testing for family members

Etiopathogenesis: Caused by Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes)
Certain strains produce erythrogenic exotoxins → hypersensitivity reaction → rash and systemic features
ModeOfTransmission: Respiratory droplets from infected or carrier individuals
InfectivePeriod: Begins during the prodrome or early febrile phase
With antibiotics: infectivity drops significantly after 24 hours

Prodrome: Vomiting, abdominal pain common in children
Tonsillar exudates, tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy
Rash: Appears within 12–48 hours of fever onset
Fine, red, sandpaper-like rash (feels like sandpaper)
Begins on neck, chest, axilla, spreads to trunk and extremities
Rash fades in 4–5 days → followed by desquamation, especially of palms and soles
OtherSigns: Strawberry tongue (white-coated tongue with red papillae early, later red beefy tongue)

DifferentialDiagnosis.Measles: Koplik spots, non-blanching rash, slower onset
DifferentialDiagnosis.DrugRash: Often itchy, lacks strawberry tongue and sore throat

Treatment: Antibiotic therapy (to prevent complications and reduce transmission): Penicillin V for 10 days (drug of choice)
Alternatives: Amoxicillin, Azithromycin (in penicillin allergy)
Antipyretics for fever
Hydration, soft diet, and rest
Prevention: Early identification and treatment of streptococcal pharyngitis
Avoid sharing utensils/toys during infectious period
No vaccine available
Exclude from school for 24 hours after starting antibiotics

Pertussis-(Whooping-Cough).description: A highly contagious respiratory disease caused by Bordetella pertussis, characterized by prolonged coughing spells and inspiratory 'whoop'
etiopathogenesis: Caused by Bordetella pertussis (Gram-negative coccobacillus)
Adheres to ciliated respiratory epithelium → releases pertussis toxin, adenylate cyclase toxin, and tracheal cytotoxin
Leads to paralysis of mucociliary apparatus → persistent cough, inflammation
No tissue invasion; damage is toxin-mediated
modeOfTransmission: Highly contagious: attack rate up to 90% in unvaccinated close contacts
infectivePeriod: Infectious up to 3 weeks after cough onset
Drops dramatically after 5 days of antibiotics

CatarrhalStage: Mild cough, coryza, sneezing, low-grade fever
Often mistaken for upper respiratory infection
ParoxysmalStage: Paroxysms of intense coughing (≥10 coughs in a single breath)
Worse at night; apnea spells in infants (life-threatening)
ConvalescentStage: Gradual reduction in severity and frequency of cough
Cough may persist for weeks ('100-day cough')

differentialDiagnosis.Bronchiolitis: Wheeze, fever, less intense cough, age <2 years
differentialDiagnosis.Foreign body aspiration: Sudden onset, localized findings, asymmetric breath sounds

complications: Subconjunctival hemorrhages, epistaxis, hernias from forceful coughing

schedule: Tdap in adolescents and pregnant women

postExposureProphylaxis: Azithromycin for close contacts (especially infants and pregnant women)

typhoidFever.description: A systemic bacterial illness caused by Salmonella Typhi, characterized by prolonged fever, abdominal symptoms, and potential complications
etiopathogenesis: Caused by Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi (Gram-negative bacillus)
Feco-oral transmission → survives gastric acid → invades intestinal mucosa → enters bloodstream
Multiplies in reticuloendothelial system (liver, spleen, bone marrow)
Bacteremia leads to systemic symptoms; reinfection of intestines → ulceration, possible perforation
modeOfTransmission: More common in areas with poor sanitation
infectivePeriod: From early illness until organism cleared from stool/urine
Chronic carriers may excrete bacteria for >1 year

Week2: Rose spots on trunk (faint salmon-colored macules)
Week4: Convalescence: slow recovery of appetite and strength

complications: Chronic carriage (especially in females, gallbladder disease)

hygiene: Food safety (avoid street food, raw salads)

tetanus.description: A potentially fatal neuroparalytic disorder caused by a neurotoxin from Clostridium tetani, characterized by muscle rigidity and spasms
etiopathogenesis: Caused by Clostridium tetani (anaerobic, spore-forming, Gram-positive bacillus)
Spores enter through wounds or umbilical stump → germinate → release tetanospasmin
Tetanospasmin blocks inhibitory neurotransmitters (GABA, glycine) → muscle hyperactivity and spasm
modeOfTransmission: Contaminated wounds: puncture, burns, surgical wounds, dental infections
Non-immunized or inadequately immunized individuals at higher risk
tetanus.incubationPeriod: 3 to 21 days (typically 7–10 days; shorter → more severe)
tetanus.infectivePeriod: Not contagious person-to-person; only infective when spores introduced into anaerobic environment

Generalized: Painful muscle spasms triggered by stimuli
Laryngospasm, apnea → may cause sudden death
Neonatal: Inability to suckle, stiffness, spasms, seizures
Localized: Muscle rigidity near injury site; may progress to generalized form

differentialDiagnosis.Dystonia: History of neurological disease or drug side effect

complications: Death due to respiratory failure or arrhythmias

antitoxin: Human Tetanus Immune Globulin (HTIG) IM — 500 IU
Equine antitoxin (if HTIG unavailable; test for hypersensitivity)
woundCare: Antibiotics: Metronidazole preferred, Penicillin G alternative

activeImmunization.DPT/Pentavalent: 6, 10, 14 weeks; boosters at 16–24 months, 5 years, 10 years; Tdap in adolescence & pregnancy

prevention.woundProphylaxis: Td booster ± HTIG if >5 years since last dose

tuberculosis.description: A chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, primarily affecting the lungs but capable of involving almost any organ
etiopathogenesis: Caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (acid-fast bacillus)
Transmitted via inhalation of aerosolized droplets from active pulmonary TB
Inhaled bacilli reach alveoli → phagocytosed → may be destroyed or multiply
Outcomes: primary, latent, progressive primary, reactivation
modeOfTransmission: Airborne droplets from coughing, sneezing, talking
Close contact in poorly ventilated areas
tuberculosis.incubationPeriod: 2 to 12 weeks for primary infection; variable for reactivation
infectivePeriod: Active pulmonary TB: contagious until 2–3 weeks of effective treatment

Extrapulmonary: Lymph node TB: painless cervical lymphadenopathy

differentialDiagnosis.Pneumonia: Acute onset, lobar findings, rapid recovery
differentialDiagnosis.Malignancy: Weight loss, cough; confirmed by biopsy

prevention.earlyDetection: Contact tracing, isoniazid prophylaxis for under-5s

leptospirosis.description: A zoonotic bacterial infection caused by Leptospira interrogans, presenting from mild flu-like illness to severe multiorgan failure
etiopathogenesis: Caused by Leptospira interrogans (spirochete)
Enters through abrasions/mucous membranes when exposed to contaminated water/soil
Rodent reservoir → spirochetemia → immune phase with organ involvement
modeOfTransmission: Contact with contaminated water, soil, food
Flooding, sewage exposure, agricultural or recreational water activities
leptospirosis.infectivePeriod: No human-to-human; animals shed bacteria for weeks to months

ImmunePhase: Weil’s disease: jaundice, hepatomegaly, oliguria, renal failure, hemorrhage, hypotension

lymeDisease.description: A multisystem infectious disease caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted through tick bites
etiopathogenesis: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi (spirochete)
Transmitted by Ixodes tick bite → localized infection → hematogenous spread

EarlyLocalized: Erythema migrans (‘bull’s eye’) at bite site
Flu-like symptoms: fever, malaise, myalgia, arthralgia

arthritis: Oral antibiotics 28 days; IV if refractory

prevention: Avoid tick areas, wear protective clothing

malaria.description: A protozoal disease caused by Plasmodium spp., transmitted by female Anopheles mosquitoes, with cyclical fever
etiopathogenesis: Caused by P. falciparum, P. vivax, P. malariae, P. ovale, P. knowlesi
Mosquito bite → sporozoites to liver → merozoites to RBCs → schizont rupture → fever spikes
P. vivax/ovale form hypnozoites → relapses
malaria.infectivePeriod: Contagious to mosquitoes while gametocytes present

Uncomplicated: Tertian (48 hr) or quartan (72 hr) fever
Severe: Pulmonary edema, ARDS, shock, renal failure

toxoplasmosis.description: A parasitic disease caused by Toxoplasma gondii, affecting immunocompromised and fetuses
etiopathogenesis: Definitive host: cats (oocysts in feces)
Transmission: ingestion of oocysts, tissue cysts, transplacental, rarely transfusion
Trophozoites invade tissues, can cross placenta
toxoplasmosis.incubationPeriod: 5–23 days post ingestion; congenital timing varies
toxoplasmosis.infectivePeriod: Cats shed oocysts 1–3 weeks; humans not significant shedders

Immunocompromised: CNS lesions, pulmonary or disseminated disease

congenitalSevere: Pyrimethamine + Sulfadiazine + Folinic acid × up to 1 year
immunocompromised: Same + ART if HIV; TMP-SMX prophylaxis

scrubTyphus.description: A mite-borne rickettsial infection caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, with fever, eschar, lymphadenopathy
etiopathogenesis: Transmitted by chigger mite bites
Organism invades endothelium → vasculitis, thrombosis
clinicalFeatures: High-grade fever, chills, headache, myalgia, GI symptoms
Severe: meningitis, pneumonia, ARDS, myocarditis, AKI

filariasis.description: A parasitic vector-borne disease caused by filarial worms, leading to lymphatic obstruction and elephantiasis
etiopathogenesis: Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, Brugia timori in lymphatics → microfilariae in blood
Host inflammation and fibrosis → obstruction

tetanusNeonatorum.description: A life-threatening neonatal condition caused by Clostridium tetani via unhygienic umbilical stump practices
etiopathogenesis: Spores enter umbilical stump → tetanospasmin release → spasm
modeOfTransmission: Contaminated instruments or dressings at birth

prevention.maternalImmunization: Two TT/Td doses during pregnancy, boosters every 10 years
